items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.62mAOD at 05:15 on 10/09/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 7 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:30 on 10/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 10/09/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 6.26 metres Chart Datum (3.21 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Thursday's early morning tide at 01:00 11/09/2025 is forecast to be 13 cm lower (3.08 mAOD). Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. We will update this message by 18:00 on 10/09/2025.

items.description: Thorney Island to West Itchenor
items.message: Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 10/09/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 5.25 metres Chart Datum (2.51 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood, front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. Thursday's early morning tide at 01:00 11/09/2025 is forecast to be 18 cm lower (2.33 mAOD). If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 on 10/09/2025.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening.   

High water on Tuesday at Plymouth is at 19:53 with flooding possible between 19:00 and 21:00. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Locations particularly at risk include exposed coastal areas of Plymouth Sound including Cawsand, Kingsand and The Hoe. 

Waterside locations and roads along the estuary may be flooded.  Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Coastal conditions should ease for Wednesday morning's high tide, however, conditions are forecast to worsen again for Wednesday evenings tide, bringing a further risk of flooding.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth on Tuesday is 2.95 mAOD.  Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level.  Force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Wednesday afternoon's tide at 13:45 on 10/09/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 6.26 metres Chart Datum (3.21 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, water will be high up slipways. If the tide comes in a little higher than we are predicting, it could be possible for a small amount of water to flow through The Shipyard, and onto Rope Walk. Thursday's early morning tide at 02:00 11/09/2025 is forecast to be 13 cm lower (3.08 mAOD). Reduced flood impacts are predicted on Thursday afternoon, before tides fall from Thursday evening. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 10/09/2025.

items.description: Dorset coast at Poole Harbour

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle at 10:30 PM on 09/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday.
High water at Plymouth on Tuesday is at 19:53 and Wednesday at 08:15. Flooding is possible an hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas of Fowey including Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park, Lostwithiel including Quay Street and the Recreation ground, East Looe and West Looe, Millendreath, Polperro Harbour, and the B3247 at Seaton.
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves. 
Coastal conditions will worsen again for both high tides on Wednesday, bringing a further risk of flooding. A flood warning is also in force. 
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth on Tuesday is 2.95 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday.   

High water at Falmouth on Tuesday is at 19:14 and Wednesday at 07:33. Flooding is possible an hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.

Low lying coastal communities are particularly at risk including Mevagissey, Portmellon, St Mawes, Swanpool, East Portholland, Par, and Polkerris. 

Take care near the coast. Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.    

Coastal conditions will worsen again for both high tides on Wednesday, bringing a further risk of flooding. A flood warning is also in force. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth on Tuesday is 2.83 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level.  Force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been updated based on a revised forecast. 

Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening, Wednesday morning and Wednesday evening. 

High water at Falmouth on Tuesday is at 19:14 and Wednesday at 07:33. Flooding is possible an hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Coastal conditions will worsen again for both high tides on Wednesday, bringing a further risk of flooding. A flood warning is also in force. 

Locations at risk may include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn Commercial Road, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Pandora Inn at Restronguet, the A390 at Tresillian. 

Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth on Tuesday is 2.83 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level.  Force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
First forecast high-water is 9:30 PM on 09/09/25 with a level of 7.67 mAOD and a Force 4 Southerly wind and second forecast high-water is 9:45 AM on 10/09/25 with a level of 7.53 mAOD and a Force 4 South-westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
Further flooding is possible at high-water until Thursday due to higher than normal tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will be closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 10:30 PM on 09/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening, Wednesday morning and Wednesday evening. High water at Ilfracombe on Tuesday evening is at 20:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.9m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 170mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and update on Thursday morning.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Tuesday evening is 5.21 mAOD, this is 0.17 metres above astronomical tide level

Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening. High water at Plymouth on Tuesday evening is at 19:45, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 4 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.8m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be around 400mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and update on Thursday morning.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth on Tuesday evening is 2.95 mAOD, this is 0.29 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast for the early hours of Wednesday 10/09/2025.
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 00:15 AM on 10/09/2025 at the following locations:
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 00:45 AM
Eastford Road, peaking around 01:00 AM
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 01:15 AM
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level not to be met during the next high tide at around midday 10/09/2025.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated 10/09/2025, by 11:00AM

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
The high tide this evening, Tuesday the 9th of September, is one in a sequence of high spring tides. Flooding to low level land and roads is possible between 9.30pm and 1.30am with the tide peaking at approximately 11.30pm. 
The high tide on Wednesday evening will be the highest in this sequence of high tides. No property flooding is currently forecast.
Areas most at risk are within the Canal foot, Sandside and Arnside areas of North Morecambe Bay.
Please avoid driving through flood water and do not put yourself or others at risk.
We will update this message by 10am on Wednesday 10 September 2025, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth
items.message:
The high tide this evening, Tuesday the 9th of September, is one in a sequence of high spring tides. Flooding to low level land and roads is possible between 9.30pm and 1.30am with the tide peaking at approximately 11.30pm. 
The high tide on Wednesday evening will be the highest in this sequence of high tides and has the possibility of property flooding around Port Carlisle with levels expected to reach 6.45m.
Please avoid driving through flood water and do not put yourself or others at risk.
We will update this message by 10am on Wednesday 10 September 2025, or sooner if the situation changes.

Hale Village, peaking around 01:00 AM
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level not to be met during the next high tide at around midday 10/09/2025.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides around 01:21AM tonight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 01:21AM on 10/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast.

Further flooding is possible tomorrow due to higher than normal tides at 01:45PM 10/09/2025 and 02:01AM 11/09/25.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible around the high tide between 11:21 PM 09/09/2025 and 3:21 AM on 10/09/2025.

We do not expect the following high tide tomorrow around 01:45PM 10/09/2025 to reach Flood Alert levels but the following nights tide will.

Areas most at risk include Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7:30am and 9:30am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.67 mAODN at 8:30am on Wednesday 10th September, which is 0.11m above tide tables, wind Force 5, South Easterly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7:30am and 9:30am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.  We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.67 mAODN at 8:30am on Wednesday 10th September, which is 0.11m above tide tables, wind Force 5, South Easterly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
Flooding is possible between 07:30 - 08:30am on Wednesday 10/09/2025. High tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths around Spurn Point. We are closely monitoring the situation.

Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are entering a period of high astronomic tides, with unsettled weather conditions for the next few days, so this alert may be re-issued if required. 

This message will be updated by 9:00am on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message: High tides may cause wave overtopping on the Tweed Estuary tomorrow morning, 10/09/2025. Tides will be at their highest between 05:00 and 06:00 AM on 10/09/2025. High tide conditions can apply two to four hours either side of a high tide. The area most likely to be affected will be Berwick Between Bridges. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
The threat of flooding from this morning's high tide has now passed, however water levels on the Tyne Estuary tomorrow morning, Wednesday 10/09/2025, will be higher than normal due to the high tide. 

Flooding is possible at riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads between 04:45 AM and 6:00 AM on 10/09/2025, however conditions can apply for two to four hours on either side of a high tide. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue the flood alert for future tides if required. 

Please be careful along riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Wednesday afternoon's tide at 13:54 on 10/09/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.24 m. The total forecast tide is 5.22 metres Chart Datum (2.49 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Impacts will be relatively minor and confined to the immediate sea front. For 30 minutes either side of high tide, water will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, but flood depths will be relatively shallow. Thursday's early morning tide at 02:09 11/09/2025 is forecast to be 13 cm lower (2.36 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 17:00 on 10/09/2025.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Lands End to Lizard Point
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening.   
High water on Tuesday at Newlyn is at 18:42 with flooding possible between 18:00 and 20:00. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas around Penzance Harbour, including Abbey Slip and Wharf Road car park, Newlyn harbour, Marazion (Green Lane area), Porthleven Harbour, and Mullion Cove. 
Waves and spray are likely so take care near the coast. Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   
Coastal conditions should ease for Wednesday morning's high tide, however, conditions are forecast to worsen again for Wednesday evenings tide, bringing a further risk of flooding.
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 3.17 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Force 3 southwesterly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:15am and 3:15am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.84 mAODN at 2:15am on Wednesday 10th September, which is 0.08m above tide tables, wind Force 4, South Easterly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.

We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 10 September.

High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a result of an ongoing period of high tides. Tides will be at their highest between 20:45 on 08/09/25 and 21:45 Wednesday, 10/09/25. Flooding to roads and low lying land adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the times of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides.
Predicted peaks at Newport 7.5m at 21:15 on 09/09 and 7.4m at 09:30 on 10/09.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 13:00 on 10/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Trent for riverside areas from Gainsborough to the Humber confluence

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby River gauge as a result of high spring tides.  Flooding is possible on high tides this evening between 7pm and 9pm on 10/09/2025.  Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road.   

We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday (11/09/2025).
We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
 
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tide on Tuesday evening.  

High water at Falmouth is at 19:14, times of high water will vary along the coast. High water levels are forecast to cause flooding between 18:00 and 20:30. 

Low lying coastal communities are particularly at risk including Mevagissey, Portmellon, St Mawes, Swanpool, East Portholland, Par, and Polkerris. 

Take care near the coast. Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   

Coastal conditions should ease by Wednesday morning. However, a flood alert remains in force, with flooding to low lying land and roads still possible over Wednesday’s high tides. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.83 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level.  Force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening.   

High water on Tuesday at Falmouth is at 19:14 with flooding possible between 18:00 and 20:30. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Locations at risk may include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn Commercial Road, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Pandora Inn at Restronguet, the A390 at Tresillian. 

Waterside properties and roads along the estuary may be flooded.  Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Coastal conditions should ease for Wednesday morning's high tide. Conditions will worsen again for Wednesday evenings tide, bringing a further risk of flooding.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.83 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level.  Force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tide on Tuesday evening. High water at Plymouth is at 19:53, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
High water levels are forecast to cause flooding between 19:00 and 21:00.
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas of Fowey including Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park, Lostwithiel including Quay Street and the Recreation ground, East Looe and West Looe, Millendreath, Polperro Harbour, and the B3247 at Seaton. 
Take care near the coast.
Coastal conditions should ease by Wednesday morning. However, a flood alert remains in force, with flooding to low lying areas possible over Wednesday’s high tides. 
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.95 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.
The tidal gate at Polperro has been closed.

items.description: Weymouth Harbour
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Weymouth Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Wey, Commercial Road Car Park, Weymouth may be inaccessible at 10:30 PM on 09/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Weymouth Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Wey, Commercial Road Car Park, Weymouth may be inaccessible.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday evening. High water at Exmouth is at 21:15, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.8m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 300mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and update on Wednesday morning.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth on Tuesday evening is 2.60 mAOD, this is 0.3 metres above astronomical tide level.
